content.webTitle: Travel woes cause staff to ponder home working

fields.headline: Travel woes cause staff to ponder home working
fields.bodyText: Travel difficulties and office politics are the two most stressful aspects of working life and are prompting an increasing number of employees to work from home, a Mori survey has revealed. The survey for Mitel Networks discovered that of office workers who cannot currently work from home, 40% would seriously consider moving jobs, and more than 25% would even take a cut in salary, to be able to work from home. The survey found that 41% of workers rate travel as the most annoying aspect of their job followed by office politics at 37%, with 33% finding constant interruptions maddening. A quarter of office workers surveyed spend between one and two hours travelling each day and 15% are late to work between one and three times a week owing to travel delays. Mitel Networks has produced a guide to Survival in the Workplace that deals with stressful aspects of working life, from coping with commuting and heavy workloads, to dealing with the constant barrage of messages, and offers advice on how to tackle each area. For a copy tel: 0870 909 3030 or email: ukmarketing@mitel.com Steve Case, of AOL Time Warner, has overtaken Chris Gent of Vodafone to grab the number one spot in Silicon.com's annual Agenda Setters 2001 report. It reveals the top 50 visionaries shaping Europe's digital economy. The Silicon.com panel of experts voted according to decision-making prowess, longevity and influence in Europe. Figures who've dropped from last year's top 10 include Rupert Murdoch, 3rd place to 25th, Michael Dell, of Dell Computers, falling from 5th to 34th and Jack Welch, boss of General Electric, drops out from 9th last year. The University of Luton is offering free foreign language courses for firms involved in e-business. The university's Languages for e-Business programme opens at Anglia Polytechnic University in Cambridge and Chelmsford on May 22. Further courses will follow in September in Luton and Ipswich. The course will equip firms with skills to help them make the most of e-business activities such as sourcing supplies online, handling foreign language emails and searching multi-lingual websites.
